name: hard coal, import from RLA | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/17518/documentation

This dataset describes the transport needed for an average export of hard coal from Latin America to North America.The average transport distance for export coal from Latin America (mostly from Colombia) is estimated to be 800km. This corresponds to the rail transport of coal between the city of La Dorada in the mining area of central Colombia and the port of Santa Maria at the Colombian Coast (VDKI, 2017). The average transport distance for import coal to Latin America is assumed to be 200km, also by rail. Only the balance of 600km is used here, as 200km are already covered in the market for hard coal, RLA. The transport via transoceanic freight ship is a rough estimate. Average coal losses and related emissions during transport and storage are included. The latter are based on generic estimates as no geography-specific data was available. Trade volumes are based on 2015 import data according to the United Nations (comtrade.org).;;Note: Discrepancies of hard coal trade volumes between different statistical sources as well as between import and export statistics of the same source are primarily due to differences in coal classification methodologies, which are not uniform on a global basis. They also occur because of coal in-transit, coal that is unaccounted for, and reporting discrepancies by importing and exporting countries.

Starting at the gate of the hard coal mine, this dataset includes the transport, re-loading and storage specific to coal exports/imports in the respective geographies. This means it includes 1.) any transport between the hard coal mine and the border of the exporting country which is required in addition to the transport needs of the domestic “market for hard coal”, 2.) the transport through transit countries (if applicable), 3.) the transoceanic freight shipping (if applicable) and 4.) any transport between the border of the importing country and the consumers which is required in addition to the transport needs of the domestic coal market.


The activity ends with the delivery of hard coal to the domestic market of the importing country.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The trade volumes represented in this dataset are based on 2015 UN trade statistics retrieved online from comtrade.org.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This datasets models the import of hard coal from Latin America to North America.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Transport of hard coal by train and transoceanic ship.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature research. The trade volumes were retrieved from UN statistics at comtrade.org for the commodity codes 270111 (Coal; anthracite, whether or not pulverised, but not agglomerated), 270112 (Coal; bituminous, whether or not pulverised, but not agglomerated), 270119 (Coal; (other than anthracite and bituminous), whether or not pulverised but not agglomerated.

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description:
Compensation for product losses. For a lack of more recent or specific data this value is based on the estimation by Dones et al. (2007) that generally 0.2% of losses occure during coal transport. It is assumed that these losses are released to the environment in the form of particulate matter > 10 micrometer. Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

The average transport distance for export coal from Latin America (mostly from Colombia) is estimated to be 800km. This corresponds to the rail transport of coal between the city of La Dorada in the mining area of central Colombia and the port of Santa Maria at the Colombian Coast (VDKI, 2017). defaultProvider.category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

exchanges.description:
Rough estimate using Google Earth and freight shipping maps. The main ports for coal exports from Colombia are Santa Marta, Rio Cordoba coal port, Puerto Drummond and Barranquilla (opensea.org, 2017). 
Reference(s): 
opensea.org. 2017. Blog: COAL: THE “BLACK GOLD” OF DRY BULK SHIPPING. Accessed online at: https://opensea.pro/blog/shipping-coal, 13 November 2017.
